thievery:Config.Setting.LockPicking: Turn Lock Picking on or off.
thievery:Config.Setting.LockPickDamageCh: Lock Pick Damage Chance. Every 4 seconds while picking, this percentage will be rolled against to determine if your pick takes damage.
thievery:Config.Setting.LockPickDamage: Lock Pick Damage. How much damage your pick takes when a failure is rolled.
thievery:Config.Setting.RequiresPilferer: Using Lockpicks requires the pilferer trait. If both this and tinkerer are true both Malefactor and Clockmaker will be able to pick locks.
thievery:Config.Setting.RequiresTinkerer: Using Lockpicks requires the tinkerer trait. If both this and pilferer are true both Malefactor and Clockmaker will be able to pick locks.
thievery:dialog-close-current: Close the currently opened lockpicking dialog first!
thievery:trait-missing-lockpick: You do not know how to use a lockpick!
thievery:need-tension-wrench: You need a tension wrench in your off-hand to use the lockpick!
thievery:no-padlock: This block doesn’t have a lock.
thievery:binding-warning: Pin {0} is binding, try a different pin.
thievery:unset-notice: You lost a set pin on {0}.
thievery:items-changed-cancel: Lockpicking cancelled: your active or off-hand item changed.
thievery:lockpick-blocked-on-claim: You can't use a lockpick on a claimed area.
thievery:thievery-text:
Thievery
Locked doors and chests are no longer simple obstacles—they’re puzzles waiting to be solved.

The Lockpicking challenges your dexterity and patience. Use a Lockpick in your main hand and a Tension Wrench in your off-hand to attempt to crack locks. Success requires careful timing, precision, and strategy.

Controls: Use walkleft and walkright to move between pins. Hold leftmouse to press a pin, and release to attempt to set it. A click sound signals either a hotspot (correct placement) or a false set. Be attentive!

Binding Pins: Some pins are “binding.” These cannot be set until non-binding pins are dealt with. If you try, you’ll receive a warning, and the pin will reset. Binding order changes dynamically as you progress.

False Sets: Higher-difficulty locks include false set positions. These mimic correct placement but will spring back later, often unsetting other pins. The harder the lock, the more false sets to watch for.

Unsetting: Mistakes or hitting false sets can randomly unset one of your already-placed pins. Stay focused and be prepared to reattempt pins as you progress.

Damage & Durability: Forcing pins incorrectly wears down your tools. Lockpicks take the brunt of mistakes, while tension wrenches degrade steadily over time as you apply pressure. Stock up before tackling difficult locks.

Difficulty Scaling: Easy locks may only have 3 pins, while brutal locks include up to 7 pins with many false sets. Harder locks also increase tool damage, false set frequency, and binding complexity.

Tip: Beginners are encouraged to practice on Copper Padlocks. They are the easiest to open and provide the perfect way to learn the rhythm of lock picking and to recognize what a true set click sounds like.

Success: Once every pin is correctly set, the lock opens automatically. Timing, recognition of audio cues, and managing risk are the keys to success.

Failure: If your lockpick or wrench breaks mid-attempt, the lock resets and you’ll need fresh tools to try again.
